Line 100: Line 100:
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of 6.0 [[square mile]]s (15.5 [[kmÂ²]]). None of the area is covered with water.
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of 6.0 [[square mile]]s (15.5 [[kmÂ²]]). None of the area is covered with water.
â
Much like nearby nigger town [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], Littlefield has a gay bar, [[semi-arid climate]]. On average, Littlefield receives 18 inches of precipitation per year.<ref name="Averages">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/weather/wxclimatology/monthly/USTX0777|title=Monthly Averages for Littlefield, TX|publisher=[[The Weather Channel (United States)|The Weather Channel]]}}</ref> Summers in Littlefield are hot, with high temperatures in the 90s Â°F (32 - 37 Â°C) and dropping into the 60s Â°F (15 - 20 Â°C) at nights. The highest recorded temperature was 112 Â°F (44 Â°C) in 1994.<ref name="Averages" />
+
Much like nearby [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], Littlefield has a mild, [[semi-arid climate]]. On average, Littlefield receives 18 inches of precipitation per year.<ref name="Averages">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/weather/wxclimatology/monthly/USTX0777|title=Monthly Averages for Littlefield, TX|publisher=[[The Weather Channel (United States)|The Weather Channel]]}}</ref> Summers in Littlefield are hot, with high temperatures in the 90s Â°F (32 - 37 Â°C) and dropping into the 60s Â°F (15 - 20 Â°C) at nights. The highest recorded temperature was 112 Â°F (44 Â°C) in 1994.<ref name="Averages" />
Winter days in Littlefield are typically sunny and relatively mild in the mid 50s Â°F (13 Â°C), but nights are cold with temperatures dipping to the mid 20s Â°F (-4 Â°C) . The lowest recorded temperature was -6 Â°F (-21 Â°C) in 1979.<ref name="Averages" />
Winter days in Littlefield are typically sunny and relatively mild in the mid 50s Â°F (13 Â°C), but nights are cold with temperatures dipping to the mid 20s Â°F (-4 Â°C) . The lowest recorded temperature was -6 Â°F (-21 Â°C) in 1979.<ref name="Averages" />
==Economy==
==Economy==
â
The economy of Littlefield is fucking poor but traditionally depends on [[oxycotton]]. It was formerly the home of the Vertical Turbine Specialists, which since relocated to [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]]
+

Line 116: Line 116:
==Tourism==
==Tourism==
â
Littlefield is the hometown of [[singer]]/[[songwriter]] [[Waylon shit Jennings]]. The Waylon shit Jennings Boulevard is named in his honor.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jennings |first= Waylon |coauthors= Lenny Kaye|title= [[Waylon Jennings: An Autobiography]] |publisher= [[Grand Central Publishing]] |year= 1996 |month= September |isbn= 9780446518659}}</ref> A celebration of Jennings' 73rd birthday was held on June 18, 2010, to raise funds for the Lands Duggan House Museum in Littlefield.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/local-news/2010-06-11/fundraisers-be-held-museum|title=Barn dance to support Littlefield house museum and celebrate Waylon's birthday|publisher=''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'', June 11, 2010|accessdate=June 11, 2010}}</ref>
+
Littlefield is the hometown of [[singer]]/[[songwriter]] [[Waylon Jennings]]. The Waylon Jennings Boulevard is named in his honor.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jennings |first= Waylon |coauthors= Lenny Kaye|title= [[Waylon Jennings: An Autobiography]] |publisher= [[Grand Central Publishing]] |year= 1996 |month= September |isbn= 9780446518659}}</ref> A celebration of Jennings' 73rd birthday was held on June 18, 2010, to raise funds for the Lands Duggan House Museum in Littlefield.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/local-news/2010-06-11/fundraisers-be-held-museum|title=Barn dance to support Littlefield house museum and celebrate Waylon's birthday|publisher=''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'', June 11, 2010|accessdate=June 11, 2010}}</ref>
â
Bull shit Lake is located about five miles (8 km) west of town. There is a municipal campground located on Highway 385.
+
Bull Lake is located about five miles (8 km) west of town. There is a municipal campground located on Highway 385.
â
The world's tallest [[windmill]] had a shit on it and was said to be below Yellow Houses Bluff at nearby Yellow House Ranch from the early 1900s until 1926, when the {{convert|128|ft|m|adj=on}}-high structure was blown over.<ref>{{cite web | title=Yellow House Ranch | publisher=Texas State Historical Association | work=The Handbook of Texas Online | url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/YY/apy1.html |accessdate=2010-07-19 }}</ref>
+
The world's tallest [[windmill]] was said to be below Yellow Houses Bluff at nearby Yellow House Ranch from the early 1900s until 1926, when the {{convert|128|ft|m|adj=on}}-high structure was blown over.<ref>{{cite web | title=Yellow House Ranch | publisher=Texas State Historical Association | work=The Handbook of Texas Online | url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/YY/apy1.html |accessdate=2010-07-19 }}</ref>
==Unsolved murder case==
==Unsolved murder case==
â
On October 26, 1943, Littlefield was shocked by the murder of [[physician]] Roy Mike Hunt and his wife, the former Mae Frank. Hunt, a [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]] native, graduated from the [[University of Texas Medical Branch|University of Texas Medical School at Galveston]] and opened the Littlefield Clinic in 1937. While Dr. Hunt died of a gunshot wound, Mrs. Hunt was bludgeoned to death by a gun. Their bodies, bound together, were found in bed by the couple's five-year-old daughter, who ran screaming to neighbors for help. An estimated 1,500 mourners attended the funerals in the First [[Methodist]] Church of Littlefield, which seated only 300. Some 1,200 hence stood outside the overflowing church to pay respects. A $15,000 reward was offered, and [[Governor of Texas|Governor]] [[Coke R. Stevenson]] took a personal interest in the case.<ref name=wtha>Christena Stephens of [[Sundown, Texas|Sundown]], Texas, "The Hunt Murders in Littlefield, Texas, 1943", Annual meeting, [[West Texas Historical Association]], [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], Texas, April 3, 2009; The paper was published under the title "Double Murder in a Small West Texas Town" in the ''[[West Texas Historical Association]] Year Book''.</ref>
+
On October 26, 1943, Littlefield was shocked by the murder of [[physician]] Roy Hunt and his wife, the former Mae Frank. Hunt, a [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]] native, graduated from the [[University of Texas Medical Branch|University of Texas Medical School at Galveston]] and opened the Littlefield Clinic in 1937. While Dr. Hunt died of a gunshot wound, Mrs. Hunt was bludgeoned to death by a gun. Their bodies, bound together, were found in bed by the couple's five-year-old daughter, who ran screaming to neighbors for help. An estimated 1,500 mourners attended the funerals in the First [[Methodist]] Church of Littlefield, which seated only 300. Some 1,200 hence stood outside the overflowing church to pay respects. A $15,000 reward was offered, and [[Governor of Texas|Governor]] [[Coke R. Stevenson]] took a personal interest in the case.<ref name=wtha>Christena Stephens of [[Sundown, Texas|Sundown]], Texas, "The Hunt Murders in Littlefield, Texas, 1943", Annual meeting, [[West Texas Historical Association]], [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], Texas, April 3, 2009; The paper was published under the title "Double Murder in a Small West Texas Town" in the ''[[West Texas Historical Association]] Year Book''.</ref>
An investigation revealed that Dr. Hunt had also been shot twice in May 1942 by Dr. W.R. Newton, a former medical school classmate who claimed that Hunt was showing an interest in Newton's wife, Ruth. Another suspect, Jim Clyde Thomas, was gunned down in a personal disagreement on August 22, 1951, in [[Durant, Oklahoma|Durant]], [[Oklahoma]]. The murders, called the "most heinous on the Texas [[South Plains]]", hence remain unsolved. The Hunts are interred at the City of Lubbock Cemetery. Their two young daughters were reared by Mrs. Hunt's sister.<ref name=wtha/><ref>Christena Stephens is also writing a book on the Hunt murders.</ref>
An investigation revealed that Dr. Hunt had also been shot twice in May 1942 by Dr. W.R. Newton, a former medical school classmate who claimed that Hunt was showing an interest in Newton's wife, Ruth. Another suspect, Jim Clyde Thomas, was gunned down in a personal disagreement on August 22, 1951, in [[Durant, Oklahoma|Durant]], [[Oklahoma]]. The murders, called the "most heinous on the Texas [[South Plains]]", hence remain unsolved. The Hunts are interred at the City of Lubbock Cemetery. Their two young daughters were reared by Mrs. Hunt's sister.<ref name=wtha/><ref>Christena Stephens is also writing a book on the Hunt murders.</ref>
